Table 3 Time interval (h) 0 − 6 6 −124 Decreasing rate of BET (m2/g·h) 2.0 1.0×10−2 Increasing rate of Ni (111)crystallite diameter(nm/h) 0.15 1.6×10−2 Research paper A novel nickel-based structured catalyst for CO2 methanation: A honeycomb-type Ni/CeO2 catalyst to transform greenhouse gas into useful resources Choji Fukuhara ⁎ Kotaro Hayakawa Yuji Suzuki Wataru Kawasaki Ryo Watanabe Department of Applied Chemistry and Biochemical Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Shizuoka University, 3-5-1 Johoku, Naka-ku, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka 432-8561, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry and Biochemical Engineering Graduate School of Engineering Shizuoka University 3-5-1 Johoku Naka-ku Hamamatsu Shizuoka 432-8561 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The purpose of this study is to construct a honeycomb-type structured catalyst with a high methanation performance to effectively transform CO2 to CH4. To select the best methanation component for structuring, a 10wt% Ni-loaded granular catalyst was prepared by evaporation to dryness using Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, Y2O3, MgO and CeO2 as the support materials. The granular Ni/CeO2 catalyst displayed the highest activity at 200–500°C, while the granular Ni/Al2O3, Ni/MgO and Ni/TiO2 catalysts showed low CO2 conversions. The variable affecting the Ni/CeO2 catalyst having a high performance would be related to the large amount of adsorbed CO2 and the production of many chemical species that originated from the CO2 on the surface. The structured catalyst with the Ni/CeO2 component was prepared by a wash-coating method on an aluminum substrate with a honeycomb-fin configuration. The prepared catalyst showed a high methanation performance, indicating that the cell density and the configuration of the honeycomb-fin clearly influenced the performance. Especially, the structured catalyst with the stacked-type-fin enhanced the methanation performance that improved the mass transfer properties in the reaction field. Furthermore, the structured Ni/CeO2 catalyst showed a steady catalytic performance that maintained the high activity and the high selectivity during a durability test at 350°C. The honeycomb-type catalyst developed in this study has the potential to be a practicable catalyst for producing energy resources from CO2. Keywords Honeycomb-type catalyst Structured catalyst CO2 methanation Cerium oxide Wash-coating 1 Introduction The CO2 methanation (eq.1, high exothermic energy) is a famous reaction called the familiar Sabatier reaction for the hydrogenation of CO2 to CH4 [1,2]. This reaction is (1) CO2 +4H2 → CH4 +2H2O (△H o 298 =−165kJ/mol) also known as a manufacturing reaction of fuel in a spaceship (closed system), combined with the electroanalysis of water. Recently, the CO2 methanation has attracted attention as a reaction that converts a greenhouse gas (namely CO2) into a useful resource gas and produces methane that is one of the hydrogen-carrier [3,4]. Such attention has thus significantly accelerated the research on catalyst development for the CO2 methanation. In many reports, most of the methanation catalysts were composed of nickel and/or precious metals (Ru and Rh) supported onto various oxide materials and zeolite materials [5–17]. These reports mainly focused on the investigation of the effects of controlling the metal condition and of different support species and its physicochemical property on the methanation performance. For constructing the methanation system from an industrial viewpoint, handling a large amount of CO2 would be required in the reaction field. In such a case, the important point is not only to develop a catalyst having the ability of effectively transforming CO2, but also to rapidly eliminate the exothermic energy from the reactive zone, because the methanation is a relatively high exothermic reaction. The packed-bed reaction system, however, could not meet this requirement because this system mainly exchanges heat energy by convective heat transfer. Development of an innovative reaction system that provides the CO2 methanation zone having a superior heat transfer property and a mass processing ability of the raw material is definitely required. A structured reaction system, which integrates a reactive zone and a heat-transferring zone, would be a candidate reaction system that provides advantages for heat exchange and material processing [18]. Namely, the structured reaction system produces a superior heat energy utilization by conductive heat transfer and also produces a decrease in the pressure drop in the reaction zone, which would allow treating a large amount of the raw material. Furthermore, the system would rapidly respond even if a load fluctuation occurs during the operation. By using an numerical simulation, we have previously proved that the structured reaction system provides such a performance when a reaction proceeds with a high reaction heat and/or with a rapid change in the feeding rate [19–21]. As for the development of the catalyst for the structured-type CO2 methanation system, little research has been reported. There is only a study for the Ni/Al-Foam catalyst prepared by chemical etching and a study for the Ni-tube-type catalyst prepared onto the inner wall of an aluminum tube by displacement plating to efficiently remove the thermal energy from the reaction field [4,22–24]. Therefore, it is necessary to accelerate the research on the development of the structured catalyst for the CO2 methanation so as to construct a structured-type methanation system. In previous studies, we developed some novel catalysts for constructing the structured reaction system though the reaction was different; i.e., (1) nickel-based, copper-based, and palladium-based catalysts prepared using the electroless plating technique on an aluminum plate for decomposition and steam-reforming of methanol and the water-gas shift reaction [25–34], (2) nickel-based honeycomb-type catalyst prepared by using the combination technique of the sol-gel method and electroless plating for the steam-reforming and the dry-reforming of methane [35–37]. In these studies, to prepare the structured-type catalyst having a high performance for a target reaction, we reported the importance of the selection of the catalyst deposition method that considered not only the selection of the catalytic component, but also the physical properties of the substrate [38]. Similar suggestion was pointed out by other reports, too [39–41]. In order to construct the structured CO2 methanation system, in this study, the methanation performances of some nickel-based catalysts prepared using various supports were first investigated for selecting the best methanation component. Using the best catalyst component, a honeycomb-type structured catalyst was prepared by the wash-coating method on an aluminum substrate, and its methanation property was investigated. The effect of the honeycomb-fin configuration on the performance was also investigated as well as the durability test. Furthermore, the ability of the honeycomb-type catalyst to be increased in the raw material gas processing was estimated compared to that of the fixed-bed reaction system. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of structured-type catalyst The preparation procedure of the honeycomb-type catalyst consisted of the following two processes: (i) preparing the nickel-based granular catalyst with a high methanation performance, and (ii) coating the nickel-based catalyst component on an aluminum fin-substrate by wash-coating. The nickel-based catalyst was a 10wt% Ni-loaded granular-type catalyst prepared by evaporation to dryness. The oxide materials as the catalyst support were Al2O3 (JRC-ALO-8), TiO2 (JRC-TIO-4), ZrO2 (JRC-ZRO-3), MgO (JRC-MGO-4) and CeO2 (JRCCEO-2), which were provided by the Catalysis Society of Japan. The Y2O3 support was prepared by calcination of Y(NO3)2·6H2O at 500°C for 3h. The support and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O were added to distilled water and well-stirred for 2h at room temperature. Thereafter, the nickel component was loaded on the support by evaporation to dryness at 80°C while stirring. The obtained powder was calcined at 500°C for 3h that formed a Ni-based granular-type catalyst. After milling for 1h, the obtained powder catalyst was first dispersed into a 2-propanol solution to prepare the slurry. The honeycomb-fin substrate (aluminum JISA1100P-H18, 18 mmφ ×45 mm-length, 96 μm-fin thickness, cell density: 100, 200cpsi, apparent surface area: 183, 265cm2) was then immersed in this slurry for 3min and dried for 5min using a drier. Before the immersion process, the aluminum substrate surface was cleaned and activated using a 0.8N-NaOH solution and a 2.8M-HCl solution. The immersing and drying processes were repeated to provide the specified catalyst weight. By drying at 27°C for 24h, the honeycomb-type catalyst was prepared. Fig. 1 shows an overview of the prepared honeycomb-type catalysts with different cell densities. The catalyst component was uniformly coated on the fin-substrate and no exfoliation of the component was observed in all the reaction tests. Fig. 2 shows the type of fin configuration used in this study. Two types of fin configurations were used. One was the honeycomb-fin with straight flow channels (18mmφ ×50 mm-length, 96 μm-fin thickness, cell density: 100cpsi, abbreviated as the plain-type). The other had random flow channels, which was constructed by connecting the plain-type fin with a 1/5 length in series (18mmφ ×10 mm-length×5 pieces, 96 μm-fin thickness, cell density: 100cpsi, abbreviated as the stacked type). 2.2 Methanation performance Using a conventional flow-type reactor, the prepared catalyst was placed in the center of the reactor tube. The catalyst was reduced by a H2 stream at 500°C for 2h before the reaction. After the reduction, reactants (CO2/H2/He: 1/4/5 molar ratio, total gas flowing volume: 70–300 ml·min−1) were supplied to the catalyst. The catalyst of 300–435mg was loaded on the honeycomb-fin substrate. The reaction temperature ranged from 200°C to 500°C. For comparing the methanation performance, the commercial catalyst (METH134, nickel-based, Clariant K.K.) was used under the same reaction conditions. The outlet gas was analyzed by GC-TCD. 2.3 Characterization of prepared catalyst The surface morphology the prepared catalyst was observed using SEM (scanning electron microscopy, JEOL, JSM-7001F). The specific surface area of the prepared catalyst was measured by the BET method (micromeritics, 3Flex) using nitrogen at its liquid temperature. The desorption profile of CO2 from the catalyst surface was measured using the CO2-TPD (BEL-CAT, Microtrac BEL). The adsorbed state of CO2 on the prepared catalyst was investigated by infrared spectroscopy using in-situ DRIFTS method. The crystal structure for the prepared catalyst was measured by X-ray diffraction (Rigaku, Ultima IV) with CuKα radiation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Investigation of suitable catalyst component for structuring For preparation of the honeycomb-type structured catalyst, it is important to coat the catalyst component, which has a high performance for the targeted reaction, onto the fin substrate. In some reports, the methanation catalyst with a high performance was mainly composed of a nickel or ruthenium component using various support materials such as Al2O3, SiO2, ZrO2, Zeolite and CeO2 [3,4]. In this section, focusing on the nickel-based catalyst from the viewpoint of manufacturing cost, we investigated the effect of the different kinds of supports on the methanation property in order to select the suitable methanation catalyst for structuring. Fig. 3 shows the effect of the different kinds of support materials, such as Al2O3, ZrO2, CeO2, TiO2, Y2O3 and MgO, on the methanation performance of the nickel-based catalyst. The granular-type catalysts used in this test weighed 300mg with a 70ml·min−1 flow rate. All the catalysts indicated a high CO2 conversion at 400°C or more, which was almost near the equilibrium value. The equilibrium value was calculated assuming the reverse water gas shift reaction (Eq. (2)) and successive CO methanation (Eq. (3)). At 350°C or below, the methanation activity was remarkably affected by the different (2) CO2 +H2 →CO+H2O (3) CO+3H2 →CH4 +H2O substrate types. Namely, the methanation activities of the Ni/MgO and Ni/TiO2 catalysts were lower than that of the other catalysts at 300°C or below, and the activity of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst also had a lower activity at 250°C or below. On the other hand, the Ni/Y2O3 and Ni/ZrO2 catalysts showed a high activity at 200–300°C. Furthermore, the Ni/CeO2 catalyst indicated the highest activity of all the tested catalyst. Such a high performance of the Ni/CeO2 catalyst for methanation was also reported by Kikuchi [42,43]. The difference in the catalyst support material has a profound effect on the methanation performance of the nickel-based catalyst. Except for the Ni/MgO catalyst at 200–350°C, the product selectivities of these catalysts were the same, which were almost equal to the equilibrium value. The remarkable CO selectivity of the Ni/MgO catalyst at the lower temperature might be caused by the strong basicity of the MgO support. The controlling factor of the methanation activity by changing the support material type was investigated over these nickel-based catalysts. Table 1 shows the BET surface area of these catalysts and the supports. Comparing the methanation performance shown in Fig. 3, the order of the surface area of the reduced catalyst and the support was not related to the order of the methanation activity. The methanation activity was not explained by the surface area of the catalyst. The mechanism of CO2 methanation over the nickel-based catalyst is generally based on a combination process of the reverse water-gas shift reaction (Eq. (2)) and successive CO methanation (Eq. (3)) [24,44,45]. Such a reaction process proceeds on the catalyst by the Langmuire-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism. Therefore, the adsorption step of the CO2 molecule onto the catalyst surface is one of the key points to provide a high methanation performance. To investigate the interaction between the CO2 molecule and the catalyst surface, the CO2-TPD profiles over the prepared catalysts were measured and characterized in Fig. 4 . Each catalysts was pre-reduced at 500°C for 1h before the measurement, and then CO2 was fed at 50°C for 1h with a successive helium purge. The ramping temperature was 10°C/min. The catalyst weight was 100mg. Focusing on the profiles of the Ni/CeO2 and Ni/ZrO2 catalysts, a large amount of adsorbed CO2 was recognized in the order of Ni/CeO2 >Ni/ZrO2. The peak top of the desorbing CO2 from both catalysts was almost the same at about 100°C. On the other hand, a small amount of CO2 adsorbed on the Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/TiO2 catalysts was detected. The peak tops of these profiles were slightly higher from the Ni/CeO2 and Ni/ZrO2 catalysts, that is about 150°C and about 220°C, respectively. The presence of a large amount of CO2 adsorbing on the surface would have a positive effect to improve the frequency factor of the rate constant of the reaction, which proceeds by the L-H mechanism, and would produce an acceleration of the methanation rate. Being on the lower temperature side of the CO2 desorption implies that the adsorbing strength of this CO2 molecule is not very strong. Considering the order of the BET surface area, the fact that the Ni/CeO2 catalyst has a large amount and a lower desorbing temperature of adsorbed CO2 would explain the high performance of this catalyst. A similar tendency was also observed for the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. The lower activity of the Ni/TiO2 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts would be related to the small amount of adsorbed CO2 and a shift in the desorption temperature to a higher value. Because the MgO support has a strong basicity, CO2 with a strong adhesion was significantly adsorbed on the Ni/MgO catalyst, regardless of the lowest surface area. Such an adhesion condition of the admolecule might prevent a reaction which progresses by the L-H mechanism on the catalyst surface. For the Ni/Y2O3 catalyst, the desorbing peak profile of CO2 on the lower temperature side widely expanded from 120°C to 280°C, which means that the adsorbed CO2 has a strong adhesion. The adsorbed CO2 was high. Considering the higher methanation activity, the reaction mechanism over the Ni/Y2O3 catalyst might be different from that of the Ni/CeO2 catalyst. As for the CO2-TPD profiles over the pure supports (CeO2, Y2O3, ZrO2, Al2O3, TiO2), the same tendency was obtained excepting the MgO support. The adsorption condition of CO2 onto the catalyst surface was next investigated. Focusing on the Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts, which have the higher BET surface areas and whose performances were quite different, the adsorbing and desorbing conditions of CO2 on these catalysts were measured by FT-IR. Fig. 5 shows the FT-IR spectra of the Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts for the CO2 adsorption and desorption. After CO2-adsorbing at 50°C and subsequent evacuation of CO2 gas for 30min, the IR spectrum was measured by ramping the temperature at an internal of 50°C. On the Ni/CeO2 catalyst, many chemical species of CO2 origin were observed; i.e., bidentate carbonate of 1614cm−1, 1296cm−1, 1214cm−1, 1040cm−1, monodentate carbonate of 1474cm−1, 1339cm−1 and carboxylate of 1575cm−1, 1395cm−1 [46,47]. On the other hand, a few chemical species were recognized on the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst; i.e., bidentate carbonate of 1640cm−1, 1428cm−1 and carboxylate of 1570cm−1, 1354cm−1 [46]. Considering that the methanation proceeds via the L-H mechanism, the observation of such many chemical species originated from the CO2 on the Ni/CeO2 catalyst suggested that this catalyst easily forms the intermediate species of the CO2 methanation compared to that of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Such carbonate and carboxylate species were also recognized on the Ni/ZrO2, Ni/Y2O3 and Ni/MgO catalysts at 50°C or higher, with the exception of the Ni/TiO2 catalyst. However, the condition of these species could not explain the methanation performance. The morphology and the acidity/basicity of the catalyst surface are thought to be related to the behavior of the adsorbed species. A further investigation of the relationship between the methanation property and the physicochemical property of the catalyst needs to clarify the factor affecting the methanation performance. 3.2 Methanation property of honeycomb-type catalyst Based on the previous section, the Ni/CeO2 catalyst was selected as a suitable methanation component for structuring. Fig. 6 shows the methanation property of the honeycomb-type catalyst prepared by wash-coating the Ni/CeO2 component on the honeycomb-fin substrate with different cell densities of 100 and 200cpsi. The flow rate of the reactant was 70ml·min−1. The honeycomb-type catalyst with 100cpsi indicated a high activity at 300°C or more and a high selectivity of methane at 400°C or below. The prepared honeycomb catalyst reflected the methanation performance of the Ni/CeO2 component shown in Fig. 3, although an obvious difference in activity was recognized at 250°C. One of the reasons for such an activity difference might be the accumulation of exothermic energy in the granular catalyst layer. Namely, the temperature of the granular-type reaction field was actually thought to be higher than the pre-set temperature, because removing the exothermic energy of methanation was not efficient in the granular layer. In fact, the temperature rise of the catalyst layer of about 20°C from the pre-set temperature was recognized in the packed-bed system. On the other hand, it was confirmed that the temperature in the honeycomb-type catalyst field was the same as the pre-set temperature. Removing the exothermic energy was efficient in the structured catalyst. The effectiveness of the heat exchanging by the fin-type structured catalyst system was experimentally confirmed in our previous study [18]. Focusing on the effect of the difference in the cell density and the catalyst weight, the increment of activity was recognized from 250°C to 350°C using a higher cell density. The degree of such increment was about 5–10%. The product selectivity of all the catalysts was the same. Based on this result, it can be expected that the activity of the structured catalyst would be controlled by changing the configuration of the fin-shape. Fig. 7 represents the effect of the fin-shape difference on the methanation performance of the prepared catalyst. Two types of fin-shapes, the plain-type with 100cpsi and the stacked type with 100cpsi, were used in this experiment. The flow rate of the reactant was 70ml·min−1. The activity of the stacked type catalyst was higher than that of the plain-type catalyst. The degree of increment was about 5–10% at 250–350°C. Such a tendency might be caused by improving the mass transfer and heat transfer by stacking the substrate in series. J.G.Khinast et al. experimentally studied the mass transfer in a ceramic wall-coated reactor with the static mixer to induce chaotic laminar flow mixing [48]. They reported that the static mixer is an advanced device, which produces an acceleration of the mass transfer and an improvement of the CO oxidation activity by mixing the gas. Miller et al. and Andersson et al. also used monolithic supports with a regular three-dimensional structure to accelerate the mass transfer, and successfully improved the CO oxidation performance [49,50]. The acceleration of the mass transfer using some devices is one of the key factors to improve the reactor performance. It was postulated that the stacked type catalyst is a candidate device for such an advanced mass transfer. According to our previous study [18], the configuration of the stacked type would have a positive performance to promote the heat-exchanging ability of the catalyst field. The detailed study about the advantage of heat transfer using the stacked catalyst as well as the mass transfer should be investigated. The structured reaction system could process a large amount of raw material gas, because of its small pressure drop in the catalyst layer. This advantage will be reflected in the reaction field that converts a large amount of CO2 into CH4. Fig. 8 shows the effect of the feeding flow rate of the raw material gas on the methanation performance of the prepared honeycomb-type catalyst, and compared with that of the fixed-bed reaction system that packed the granular-type commercial catalyst (METH134) and the granular-type Ni/CeO2 catalyst. The loaded weight of these catalyst components of 300mg were the same. For both fixed-bed systems, the conversions significantly decreased when increasing the feeding flow rate. At the high feeding flow rate, a negative effect on mass transfer in the fixed-bed layer was generated and significantly deteriorated the methanation performance. On the other hand, the performance of the honeycomb-type catalyst did not change very much when increasing the feeding flow rate. The structured catalyst indicated a relatively constant activity until the 300ml·min−1 flow rate, although the WHSV based on the net weight of the coated catalyst changed from 14,000ml·g−1·h−1 to 60,000ml·g−1·h−1. The rectification flow in the structured channel would have a positive effect on the mass transfer in the catalyst layer. At the 300ml·min−1 flow rate, the line velocity was 40.8mm·s−1. Such a line velocity suggested that the residence time of the raw material gas in the catalyst layer was about 1.0s. The high selectivity to methane was maintained even at the high flow rate. Based on these results, it was thought that the prepared honeycomb-type catalyst has a rapid transforming ability for the CO2 methanation. 3.3 Durability performance of honeycomb-type Ni/CeO2 catalyst To develop a catalyst having a long life is one of the fundamental factors to construct a reaction system from the view point of commercial manufacturing. Furthermore, in the case of developing a structured-type catalyst, which is prepared on any substrate, the avoidance of catalyst exfoliation from the substrate is strongly required as well as a long catalyst performance life. Fig. 9 shows the durability performance and product selectivity of the stacked type Ni/CeO2 catalyst with 100cpsi. The reaction temperature was 350°C and the flow rate of the reactant was 70ml·min−1. The prepared honeycomb-type catalyst showed a stable performance during the durability test. Namely, the conversion was stable, being almost equal to the equilibrium, and the selectivity to CH4 also did not decrease. No exfoliation of the catalyst component was observed during the test. The developed catalyst has a high and practical potential for use as a catalyst for constructing a CO2 methanation reactor with the structured configuration. Fig. 10 indicates the surface morphology of the honeycomb-type catalyst before and after the durability test. No obvious difference in the particle configuration was observed after 124h, although a somewhat smaller particle was slightly recognized. Table 2 shows the BET surface area, the crystallite diameters of the Ni(111) and CeO2(111) for the catalyst before the reaction, and after a 6 or 124h pass. The crystallite diameters were estimated from the XRD profiles of these catalysts using Scherrer's equation. In addition, Table 3 shows the changing rate of surface morphology change at different time intervals, based on the data shown in Table 2. Due to the sintering phenomena, the increase in the nickel diameter and the decrease in the BET surface area were recognized during the reaction. However, the decreasing degree of the BET surface area was different between 0 and 6h and 6–124h as well as the increasing degree of the nickel diameter. Namely, the decreasing degree of the BET surface area from 6 to 124h was quite lower than that from 0 to 6h, and the increasing degree of the nickel diameter also had the same tendency. In addition, the crystallite diameter of CeO2 did not change very much. Such results suggested that the surface condition of the Ni/CeO2 particle was relatively stable, though it changed by heating, etc., during the initial stage. It was thought that, by the addition of some promoter component that prevents the sintering of the nickel particle or by optimization of the nickel preparation process, a further extension of the life of the Ni/CeO2 catalyst would be possible. The investigation from such a viewpoint will be needed for accelerating the practicality of the structured Ni/CeO2 catalyst in the next study. 4 Conclusions The Ni/CeO2 was selected as a suitable catalyst component for the CO2 methanation compared to the Ni/Al2O3, Ni/TiO2 and Ni/Y2O3 catalysts. The honeycomb-type Ni/CeO2 catalyst was successfully prepared on an aluminum-fin substrate using the wash-coating method. The prepared honeycomb-type catalyst showed a high methanation performance, indicating that the cell density and the configuration of the honeycomb-fin clearly influenced the performance. Especially, the structured catalyst with the stacked-type-fin enhanced the performance so as to improve the properties of the mass transfer in the reaction field. The prepared honeycomb-type catalyst showed a steady catalytic performance that maintained a high activity and high selectivity during the durability test at 350°C. coredata.dc:description: The purpose of this study is to construct a honeycomb-type structured catalyst with a high methanation performance to effectively transform CO2 to CH4. To select the best methanation component for structuring, a 10wt% Ni-loaded granular catalyst was prepared by evaporation to dryness using Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, Y2O3, MgO and CeO2 as the support materials. The granular Ni/CeO2 catalyst displayed the highest activity at 200–500°C, while the granular Ni/Al2O3, Ni/MgO and Ni/TiO2 catalysts showed low CO2 conversions. The variable affecting the Ni/CeO2 catalyst having a high performance would be related to the large amount of adsorbed CO2 and the production of many chemical species that originated from the CO2 on the surface. The structured catalyst with the Ni/CeO2 component was prepared by a wash-coating method on an aluminum substrate with a honeycomb-fin configuration. The prepared catalyst showed a high methanation performance, indicating that the cell density and the configuration of the honeycomb-fin clearly influenced the performance. Especially, the structured catalyst with the stacked-type-fin enhanced the methanation performance that improved the mass transfer properties in the reaction field. Furthermore, the structured Ni/CeO2 catalyst showed a steady catalytic performance that maintained the high activity and the high selectivity during a durability test at 350°C. The honeycomb-type catalyst developed in this study has the potential to be a practicable catalyst for producing energy resources from CO2.
coredata.dc:title: A novel nickel-based structured catalyst for CO2 methanation: A honeycomb-type Ni/CeO2 catalyst to transform greenhouse gas into useful resources
